section.p: Sir Isaac Newton's three laws of motion describe the motion of massive bodies and how they interact. While Newton’s laws may seem obvious to us today, more than three centuries ago they were considered to be revolutionary. Newton was one of the most influential scientists of all time.

stack.name: wrapTitle2
stack.p: 35 Also known as 'The law of Inertia'
"In the non-existence of an unbalenced force, an object in motion will continue in motion."
justify - A stationary object will move only if there is any unbalenced force acting on it.
justify60 - A moving object will change direction or speed only if there is any unbalenced force acting on it.
justify Use the sliders to controll the amount of friction in the simulation.

justify Note: Friction is the force resisting the relative motion of solid surfaces, fluid layers, and material elements sliding against each other. In this simulation the unbalenced force acting on the object is friction.

Before getting into the Newton's second law, we must first understand what is acceleration.
40 Acceleration : The rate of change in the velocity of an object.

p.b: Newton's second law of motion states:

stack.p: - The greater the mass of an object, the more force it will take to accelerate the object.
30 $ Force = Mass \cdot Acceleration $
30 $ F = m \cdot a $
60 Where F is measured in Newtons, m is measured in kg, and a is measured in m/s (meter/secod).

p.b: Newton's third law of motion states:

stack.p: - For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.
- Whenever an object pushes another object, it gets pushed back in the opposite direction equally hard.
